study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of green tea against methotrexate-induced cytotoxicity in the submandibular salivary glands of rats.
results_summary: Green tea showed significant improvement in the histological condition of the submandibular salivary glands compared to methotrexate alone and pomegranate peel extract, demonstrating stronger antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anticancer properties of green tea extract (GTE) and epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG) in a 3D MCF-7 breast cancer cell culture model.
results_summary: GTE inhibited cell migration and spheroid formation more effectively than EGCG, while also inducing more pronounced morphological changes in the spheroids' structure, suggesting that the food matrix enhances GTE's anticancer potential.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cell line in a 3D culture model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether EGCG (a component of green tea) improves iron status by reducing inflammation in iron-deficient rats.
results_summary: EGCG reduced serum amyloid A (SAA) concentrations but did not improve serum iron levels or other iron markers. No significant effects were observed on CRP, hepcidin, or liver iron concentrations.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats fed an iron-deficient diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether combining human bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (hBM-MSCs) and green tea extract (GTE) enhances retinal ganglion cell survival and axonal regeneration after optic nerve injury.
results_summary: Combined treatment of hBM-MSCs and GTE promoted retinal ganglion cell survival and neurite outgrowth/axonal regeneration in both ex vivo retinal explant culture and in rats with optic nerve injury. GTE increased Stat3 activation in the retina and enhanced brain-derived neurotrophic factor secretion from hBM-MSCs, while inhibiting their proliferation, migration, and differentiation in vitro.
population_specificity: Rats with optic nerve injury and ex vivo retinal explant cultures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Green Tea Extract (GTE) in reversing the negative effects of bleaching on enamel adhesion and marginal leakage compared to other antioxidants and treatments.
results_summary: GTE (5%) improved bond strength and reduced microleakage compared to the control group, though sodium ascorbate (SA) performed better. GTE was concluded as a potential alternative to SA for enamel reversal post-bleaching.
population_specificity: Human first premolar teeth (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiviral efficacy of EGCG (a polyphenol in green tea) against influenza viruses in vitro and in ferrets.
results_summary: EGCG showed antiviral activity in vitro with selective indices ranging from 16-96, but it failed to reduce viral replication in ferrets, unlike oseltamivir which significantly lowered viral load.
population_specificity: Ferrets (in vivo) and MDCK/Calu-3 cells (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different doses of green tea on renal function, lipid profiles, and HbA1c in patients with type 2 diabetes and nephropathy.
results_summary: Consuming three cups of green tea (7.5 g/day) significantly reduced total cholesterol and HbA1c while increasing HDL-C, with no adverse effects on renal function. No significant differences were observed for other variables.
population_specificity: 66 individuals with type 2 diabetes and nephropathy, aged 30-70 years.
effective_dosage: Three cups (7.5 g/day) or two cups of green tea per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardiovascular health benefits of flavan-3-ols, particularly from green tea catechins, and explore the potential role of microbiota in these effects.
results_summary: Green tea catechins demonstrated better cardiovascular benefits in healthy individuals, improving endothelial function and reducing blood pressure. The effects may involve microbial metabolites influencing gene expression and protein function.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an electrochemical biosensor using Ag/SrFeO3 nanostructures to detect caffeic acid (CA) in green tea and coffee without pre-treatment.
results_summary: The modified Ag/SrFeO3 electrode demonstrated excellent electrocatalytic activity for CA detection, with a wide linear range (1-15 nM), low detection limit (23 nM), good stability, and repeatability. The biosensor showed potential for real-time CA detection in commercial green tea and coffee.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of green tea extract supplementation on body composition, obesity-related hormones, and oxidative stress markers.
results_summary: The study found that green tea extract supplementation had beneficial effects on some body composition markers and oxidative stress, but evidence regarding obesity-related hormones was inconclusive. The meta-analysis indicated mixed results across different outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of green tea-derived natural products in supporting resistance training-induced adaptations to prevent or attenuate age-related muscle mass loss.
results_summary: The study suggests that green tea-derived natural products may assist in the growth or maintenance of skeletal muscle and delay the onset of age-related metabolic diseases in older adults, based on evidence from animal and clinical studies.
population_specificity: Older adults at risk of sarcopenia or age-related muscle loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of six-week aerobic training combined with green tea supplementation on cardiovascular markers in young obese men.
results_summary: Body Mass Index and fat percentage significantly decreased in groups combining aerobic exercise with green tea, aerobic exercise alone, and green tea alone compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Young obese men aged 28-35 years.
study_duration: Six weeks (18 sessions of aerobic exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of Green Tea supplementation on weight, BMI, and waist circumference in overweight and obese women through a meta-analysis of RCTs.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study sought to address inconsistencies in the literature regarding Green Tea's effects on weight-related metrics in obese women.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of green tea on blood pressure in healthy individuals by synthesizing randomized controlled studies to minimize confounding factors.
results_summary: Green tea supplementation reduced systolic blood pressure by 2.99 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure by 0.95 mmHg in healthy individuals, with statistically significant results and no observed publication bias.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals (mean age ~35-36 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a 60-day dietary supplementation with Green Tea on weight gain and visceral fat in menopausal women.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Green Tea's effects.
population_specificity: Menopausal women experiencing weight gain and increased visceral fat.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential benefits of (-)-Epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG), a compound in green tea, in treating age-related macular degeneration (AMD), particularly its effects on the retinal pigment epithelium and neural retina.
results_summary: The study suggests that EGCG may downregulate pathways involved in AMD progression, particularly in wet AMD, by targeting vascular endothelial growth factor A (VEGFA). However, it does not provide conclusive evidence on its effectiveness for dry AMD.
population_specificity: Individuals with age-related macular degeneration (AMD), specifically dry and wet forms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining green tea catechins with exercise improves body composition outcomes in overweight and obese populations beyond the effects of exercise alone.
results_summary: The study found that green tea catechins may modulate fat and energy metabolism, but clinical effects remain controversial. The review assessed whether supplementation with green tea catechins alongside exercise training further enhances exercise-induced changes in body composition.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese populations

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if green tea intake could influence the prevention of COVID-19 by boosting immunity and improving sleep.
results_summary: The study suggested that green tea intake, along with adequate hydration and vitamin supplementation, may increase chances of avoiding COVID-19 infection and improve sleep quality. However, specific efficacy data or statistical significance for green tea alone was not detailed.
population_specificity: General population under lockdown conditions (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of green tea extract (GTE) on vascular and metabolic responses in older adults compared to a placebo.
results_summary: GTE increased postprandial muscle and cerebral macrovascular blood flow and improved leg glucose/insulin metabolic responses in healthy older adults.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy older adults (42% male, average age 74 ± 1 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of tea supplements, particularly green tea, as an adjuvant therapy for women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: The study found that tea supplementation, especially green tea, significantly decreased fasting blood glucose (FBG) and fasting insulin (FINS) levels, reduced body weight, and improved reproductive hormone indexes in women with PCOS. The therapy was also deemed relatively safe.
population_specificity: Women diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of green tea supplementation on exercise-induced oxidative stress.
results_summary: Acute green tea ingestion did not influence antioxidant status or reduce oxidative stress, but supplementation for over 1 week (400-800 mg catechins/day) increased total antioxidant status and protected against exercise-induced oxidative stress. Future studies should focus on longer supplementation periods before and after exercise.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing exercise (specific population not detailed).
effective_dosage: 400 to 800 mg of catechins per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic decaffeinated green tea extract (dGTE) supplementation affects lipolysis and fat oxidation during arm cycle exercise in men and women.
results_summary: The study found that chronic dGTE supplementation had no effect on lipolysis or fat oxidation during arm cycle exercise in either men or women.
population_specificity: Eight adults (23-37 years old, 4 women)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight how European regulations lead to different commercial classifications for botanical products like Green Tea, affecting their market availability and claims.
results_summary: The study found that Green Tea, like other botanicals, is sold under various classifications (e.g., food supplements, medicinal products) in the EU due to regulatory inconsistencies, but did not assess its specific effects or safety.
population_specificity: Not specified (general EU market analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of green tea intake on disease symptoms and laboratory parameters (CRP, ESR, CBC) in patients with mild-to-moderate Covid-19 infection.
results_summary: The abstract does not report results, as it describes a planned study protocol rather than completed findings.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥18 years with mild-to-moderate Covid-19 infection admitted to Yasuj Shahid Jalil Hospital in Iran.
effective_dosage: Two capsules containing 450 mg green tea extract, taken twice daily after meals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between daily Matcha Green Tea Powder supplementation and cognitive function changes in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found significant cognitive enhancement in elderly women, as measured by the MoCA score, and an inverse correlation between dietary vitamin K intake and MoCA score changes. No significant effects were reported for men.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling elderly people (61 participants, gender-specific analysis performed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on recovery strategies in combat sports, including the role of green tea as an evidence-supported supplement.
results_summary: The study found that green tea, among other supplements, improves recovery processes in combat sports, though specific effects and mechanisms were not detailed.
population_specificity: Combat sports athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of green tea supplementation on serum adiponectin concentrations in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The meta-analysis of five randomized controlled trials (RCTs) involving 333 T2DM patients showed that green tea supplementation significantly increased adiponectin concentrations compared to control groups. The results suggest a beneficial effect of green tea on adiponectin levels in this population.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the efficacy of green tea supplementation on anthropometric indices and body composition in type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) patients through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Green tea consumption significantly reduced body weight, BMI, and body fat, particularly in long-term interventions (>8 weeks), at lower doses (≤800 mg/day), and in overweight patients. The study concluded that green tea has beneficial effects on these outcomes in T2DM patients.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) patients, particularly overweight individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of epigallocatechin 3-gallate (EGCG) from green tea to counteract hyper-inflammation in COVID-19 by modulating cytokine production and autoimmune responses.
results_summary: The study found that EGCG inhibits key pro-inflammatory transcription factors (STAT1/3 and NF-κB), reduces cytokine production, and exhibits anti-fibrotic effects, suggesting its potential as a safe supplement to mitigate severe inflammation in COVID-19.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients with potential cytokine storm syndrome (theoretical application based on autoimmune disease mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of combining HIIT and green tea supplementation on serum levels of SIRT1, PGC-1α, and CAT, as well as antioxidant system improvements in sedentary overweight women.
results_summary: The study found that 10 weeks of HIIT and green tea significantly increased serum levels of SIRT1, PGC-1α, and CAT, with the HIIT + green tea group showing the most pronounced effects. Additionally, SIRT1 and CAT levels increased significantly in response to acute exercise across all groups.
population_specificity: Thirty sedentary overweight women (n=10 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the acute effects of low and high doses of a green tea-based supplement on brachial artery blood flow before and after resistance exercise.
results_summary: The study found that a high dose (600 mg) of green tea-based supplement increased blood flow immediately after exercise compared to placebo, but no effect was observed with the low dose (300 mg). No differences were found in brachial artery diameter between supplement and placebo at any time point.
population_specificity: College-aged males who self-reported recreational resistance training for the previous 6 ± 3 years.
study_duration: Acute (effects measured within 45 minutes post-ingestion and post-exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of green tea on blood lipids through a literature review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Green tea intake significantly lowered total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol but did not affect HDL cholesterol. Triglycerides were reduced, though not significantly. No significant publication bias was found.
population_specificity: 3321 subjects, including both normal weight and overweight/obese individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and dose-response relationship of green tea on obesity indices in humans through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found that green tea supplementation significantly reduced body weight (-1.78 kg) and BMI (-0.65 kg/m²), with heterogeneity attributed to dosage, extract type, and intervention duration.
population_specificity: Obese subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of L-theanine (L-THE) supplementation on stress responses and anxiety levels in humans through randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found that 200-400 mg/day of L-THE may help reduce stress and anxiety in individuals exposed to stressful conditions, though longer-term and larger studies are needed for clinical validation.
population_specificity: People exposed to stressful conditions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of green tea supplementation on blood pressure control through a meta-analysis of randomized placebo-controlled trials.
results_summary: The pooled results showed that green tea significantly lowered both systolic and diastolic blood pressure, with mean reductions of -1.17 mm Hg and -1.24 mm Hg, respectively. No significant publication bias was detected, though heterogeneity was noted among the studies.
population_specificity: 1697 subjects across 24 trials (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Short-term trials (exact duration not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of EGCG, an active ingredient in green tea, to prevent and treat digestive tract tumors by examining its mechanisms of action and clinical applications.
results_summary: The study found that EGCG can antagonize digestive tract tumors by preventing tumor development, inducing cell cycle arrest, and promoting apoptosis. However, it noted limitations such as poor stability and low bioavailability.
population_specificity: General human population, with a focus on digestive tract tumor prevention and treatment.
interactions: Synergistic use with cancer drugs was mentioned to enhance efficacy and reduce anti-allergic properties.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of decaffeinated green tea extract on circulating sex hormones and insulin-like growth factor proteins in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that 12-month supplementation with green tea extract significantly increased circulating estradiol and bioavailable estradiol levels compared to placebo, but had no effect on IGF proteins.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal women (mean age ~60 years).
effective_dosage: 4 capsules daily (1315 mg total catechins, including 843 mg epigallocatechin-3-gallate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of six-week green tea extract supplementation combined with CrossFit workouts on blood antioxidant status and serum BDNF levels in men.
results_summary: Green tea extract supplementation significantly increased SOD activity and FRAP levels, moderately attenuated lipid peroxidation, but had marginal effects on aerobic capacity and BDNF levels. No significant differences were observed in other antioxidant measures like CAT, GPx, GR, GSH, or BDNF.
population_specificity: Young males involved in CrossFit training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential therapeutic functions of green tea polyphenols, focusing on their molecular mechanisms, bioavailability, and health benefits.
results_summary: The study found that green tea polyphenols exhibit antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anticancer, and other health-promoting properties, with potential benefits for chronic conditions like cardiovascular disease, cancer, and diabetes. The effects are primarily linked to the structure and composition of polyphenols, particularly EGCG.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health perspective).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of green tea extract (GTE) on LDL-C and leptin levels in overweight and obese women with high LDL-C.
results_summary: GTE supplementation for 6 weeks significantly reduced LDL-C by 4.8% and increased leptin by 25.7%, but showed no significant effects on total cholesterol, triglycerides, or HDL.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese women (BMI ≥ 27 kg/m²) aged 18-65 with high LDL-C.

study_goal: The researchers examined the association between green tea extract-based dietary supplements and hepatotoxicity, focusing on identifying causality in multi-ingredient HDS-related liver injury.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that green tea extract-based dietary supplements are among the groups associated with hepatotoxicity, illustrating challenges in determining causality in multi-ingredient HDS-related liver injury. No specific efficacy outcomes for green tea are mentioned.
population_specificity: Not specified (general dietary supplement consumers)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether green tea extract supplementation reduces exercise-induced muscle soreness, muscle damage, and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Green tea extract supplementation reduced muscle damage markers but did not affect muscle soreness or oxidative stress. It suggests positive effects on muscle recovery after strenuous exercise.
population_specificity: Twenty non-trained men.

study_goal: To investigate whether daily consumption of green tea improves clinical outcomes in patients with chronic periodontitis after scaling and root planning.
results_summary: Green tea consumption significantly reduced probing depth and bleeding index compared to the control group, though plaque index reduction was not significantly different between groups. The study concluded that green tea can enhance the effects of periodontal therapy.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with chronic periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of an anti-inflammatory nutrition supplement containing green tea extract on insulin resistance and adiponectin biology in overweight adolescents.
results_summary: The supplement maintained high-molecular-weight adiponectin levels and reduced HOMA-IR in 40% of participants, particularly those with higher baseline metabolic risk. Green tea extract's effects were linked to bidirectional modulation of adipogenic gene methylation.
population_specificity: Overweight adolescents aged 13-18 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (part of a multi-ingredient supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether green tea extract (GTE) supplementation modifies mammographic density (MD) as a potential mechanism for its protective role against breast cancer.
results_summary: GTE supplementation for 12 months did not significantly change percent or absolute MD in all women, but it significantly reduced percent MD by 4.40% in younger women (50-55 years) compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 1,075 healthy postmenopausal women (932 completers).
effective_dosage: 4 decaffeinated GTE capsules daily (1,315 mg total catechins, including 843 mg EGCG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a 28-day supplementation with a polyphenol blend from Camellia sinensis on intramuscular apoptotic signaling following resistance exercise and recovery.
results_summary: The study found that the polyphenol blend altered apoptotic signaling in skeletal muscle post-exercise, with significant differences in phosphorylation markers (e.g., BAD, JNK, Bcl-2) compared to placebo and control groups. Chronic supplementation showed measurable effects on apoptotic pathways, particularly at 1H, 5H, and 48H post-exercise.
population_specificity: Untrained males (n=38, aged 21.8±2.7 years, 173.4±7.9 cm, 77.6±14.6 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 8-week green tea extract (GTE) supplementation enhances postexercise muscle glycogen resynthesis and systemic energy substrate utilization in young college students.
results_summary: GTE supplementation did not improve muscle glycogen resynthesis but increased postexercise fat oxidation and muscle GLUT4 protein content compared to placebo. No differences were observed in blood glucose or insulin responses between GTE and placebo trials.
population_specificity: Eight healthy male college students (mean age 22, BMI 24.2, VO2max 43.2 ml/kg per min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of green tea on disease activity and quality of life in systemic lupus erythematosus patients.
results_summary: The study demonstrated anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory benefits of green tea in autoimmune disease, specifically systemic lupus erythematosus, though specific outcome details are not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: 68 systemic lupus erythematosus patients aged 39.1 ± 10.3 years with a BMI of 25.7 ± 5.21 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential effects of green tea catechins, particularly EGCG, on reducing oxidative stress in male and female reproductive health.
results_summary: The study found that green tea catechins, especially EGCG, exhibit strong antioxidant properties that may improve gamete quality by reducing oxidative stress, potentially enhancing sperm motility in males and oocyte maturation in females.
population_specificity: Males and females with reproductive health concerns related to oxidative stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of green tea extract as an adjunctive treatment for pain and physical function in adults with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that green tea extract significantly reduced VAS pain, total WOMAC, and WOMAC physical function scores compared to the control group, but no significant differences were observed for WOMAC pain and stiffness scores. Only one adverse event (gastric upset) was reported in the control group.
population_specificity: Adults with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if acute green tea supplementation reduces inflammatory and oxidative stress biomarkers and modulates miRNA expression in obese women after consuming a high-fat, high-saturated meal.
results_summary: Green tea did not affect inflammatory or oxidative stress biomarkers but significantly reduced the expression of 62 miRNAs, with five miRNAs linked to key metabolic pathways.
population_specificity: Obese women over 18 years old without comorbidities.
effective_dosage: 738 mg (2 capsules) taken once before fasting overnight.
study_duration: Acute (single-dose intervention with follow-up measurements 5 hours post-meal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of green tea in preventing prostate cancer (PCa) among various dietary and lifestyle factors.
results_summary: The study suggests that green tea may play a role in PCa prevention based on epidemiological, in vivo, in vitro, and early clinical studies, but more research is needed to confirm its effectiveness.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on prostate cancer risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether EGCG consumption increases energy expenditure and promotes fat oxidation based on randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis revealed that EGCG supplementation showed a significant mean difference compared to placebo for respiratory quotient and fat oxidation, indicating potential benefits for energy metabolism.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the regulatory effects of green tea extract (GTE) on biomarkers related to colorectal cancer (CRC) oncogenesis, including selenoproteins, WNT signaling, inflammation, and methylation.
results_summary: GTE supplementation significantly reduced rectal DNA methyltransferase (DNMT1) and NF-κB mRNA levels, indicating potential anti-inflammatory and epigenetic regulatory effects. However, it did not significantly affect acetylated histone H3, Ki-67 expression, or plasma C-reactive protein, and combining GTE with Brazil nuts did not enhance effects beyond either agent alone.
population_specificity: Thirty-two volunteers over 50 years of age with plasma selenium levels ≤1.36 µmol/l.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of green tea extract on blood pressure, endothelial function, metabolic profile, and inflammatory activity in obese prehypertensive women.
results_summary: The study found that green tea extract significantly reduced systolic blood pressure over 24 hours, daytime, and nighttime compared to placebo, but no significant changes were observed in diastolic blood pressure or other measured parameters.
population_specificity: Obese prehypertensive women (mean age 41.1 ± 8.4 years).
effective_dosage: 500 mg of green tea extract (260 mg polyphenols per capsule) daily, divided into 3 capsules.
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention with a 2-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether green tea polyphenol supplementation (GTPS) could protect against oxidative stress and DNA damage induced by exposure to extremely low frequency electromagnetic fields (ELF-EMFs) from high-voltage power lines.
results_summary: GTPS significantly reduced oxidative stress (measured by urinary 8-isoprostane and 8-OHdG) in workers exposed to ELF-EMFs after 12 months, but this protective effect disappeared three months after discontinuing GTPS.
population_specificity: Workers with or without exposure to ELF-EMFs from 110-420kV power lines (n=867).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of green tea extract (GTE) supplementation on post-prandial responses to a high-carbohydrate meal, focusing on appetite-associated hormones and glucose homeostasis, while considering the influence of COMT genotype.
results_summary: GTE supplementation did not affect leptin, ghrelin, adiponectin, or satiety responses but showed higher insulin concentrations in participants with the high-activity COMT genotype compared to placebo and low-activity COMT groups.
population_specificity: 60 Caucasian post-menopausal women with a BMI ≥ 25.0 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a green tea extract could enhance leukocyte function and improve plasma antioxidant status in humans.
results_summary: The study found that 14 days of green tea extract supplementation significantly increased leukocyte release of myeloperoxidase and lactoferrin, as well as total plasma antioxidant status, but did not significantly affect leukocyte counts.
population_specificity: Healthy human volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of green tea supplementation on plasma CRP concentrations through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 11 RCTs found no significant effect of green tea catechins on plasma CRP concentrations, regardless of supplementation duration or dosage. Subgroup analyses also showed no significant effects in healthy subjects or those with cardiometabolic diseases.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects and participants with cardiometabolic diseases.
effective_dosage: <400 mg/d and ≥400 mg/d of total catechins.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination supplement containing green tea (100 mg) could reduce blood pressure in hypertensive subjects with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The supplement reduced diastolic blood pressure by 4.4 mm Hg but did not significantly affect systolic pressure. In vitro data suggested the polyphenol combination enhanced nitric oxide production via eNOS activation.
population_specificity: Hypertensive individuals with metabolic syndrome (systolic BP ≥130 mm Hg or diastolic BP ≥85 mm Hg).
effective_dosage: 100 mg green tea extract (as part of a multi-component supplement).
study_duration: 28-day intervention periods separated by a 2-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral green tea catechins (GTCs) could protect against UVR-induced skin inflammation, erythema, and biochemical markers in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that oral GTCs (1080 mg/day) with vitamin C over 3 months did not significantly reduce UVR-induced skin erythema, leukocyte infiltration, or eicosanoid responses compared to placebo. No statistically significant differences were observed between the active and placebo groups for any measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 18-65 years with phototypes I-II (fair skin).
effective_dosage: 1350 mg green tea extract (540 mg GTCs) with 50 mg vitamin C, twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effects of green tea extract (GTE) on breast cancer biomarkers, including mammographic density, in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in overall adverse events between GTE and placebo groups, though GTE was associated with higher nausea, dermatologic effects, and ALT elevations, and lower diarrhea incidence. Most adverse events were mild and transient, suggesting GTE is generally well tolerated.
population_specificity: Predominantly Caucasian postmenopausal women (n=1075).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review hepatic adverse reactions associated with green tea-based herbal supplements and assess causality.
results_summary: The study identified 19 cases of hepatotoxicity linked to green tea consumption, with most cases involving hepatocellular damage. Reactions were more severe in multicomponent preparations, sometimes requiring liver transplantation, while standalone green tea reactions had longer latency but resolved fully.
population_specificity: Cases of hepatotoxicity reported in individuals consuming green tea or multicomponent herbal supplements (mostly women).
study_duration: Latency varied (179.1 ± 58.95 days for GT, 44.7 ± 13.85 days for MC preparations).
interactions: Multicomponent preparations containing other hepatotoxic ingredients increased risk of liver damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of green tea or green tea extract (GTE) supplementation on blood pressure (BP) among overweight and obese adults through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Green tea or GTE supplementation resulted in a small but statistically significant reduction in both systolic and diastolic blood pressure compared to placebo, though the quality of evidence across studies was low.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (47% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether green tea supplementation reduces DNA damage and enhances cytoprotective responses (hOGG1 activity and HMOX-1 protein levels) in Type 2 diabetes subjects.
results_summary: Green tea significantly reduced DNA damage (~15%), increased hOGG1 activity (~50%), and raised HMOX-1 protein levels (~40%), with no changes in mRNA expression. Responses were similar across different HMOX-1 promoter polymorphism groups.
population_specificity: 43 Type 2 diabetes subjects (20 with short GT repeats, 23 with long GT repeats in the HMOX-1 promoter region).
effective_dosage: 2 × 150 ml of 1% w/v tea per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of green tea extract (GTE) supplementation on oxidative stress and muscle damage markers in sprinters during their preparatory training phase.
results_summary: GTE supplementation increased total polyphenols and antioxidant capacity at rest and reduced oxidative stress markers after exercise, but did not prevent muscle damage or improve sprint performance.
population_specificity: Sixteen sprinters during their preparatory training phase.

study_goal: The researchers were exploring the potential of green tea polyphenols as additives to sunscreens or stand-alone products to modulate the immunosuppressive effects of UVR on the skin.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that green tea polyphenols, along with other plant polyphenols, show promise in modulating UVR-induced immunosuppression, potentially offering protective benefits against skin cancer. However, specific efficacy data or clinical outcomes are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on UVR exposure and skin cancer risk)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a polyphenol complex containing green tea and blueberry could enhance antiviral and antibacterial properties in athletes during intense exercise.
results_summary: The study found that the serum from athletes supplemented with the polyphenol complex (including green tea) significantly protected cells from viral infection and delayed virus replication post-exercise, though it did not show antibacterial effects.
population_specificity: Long-distance runners undergoing intensified training.
effective_dosage: 40 g/day of the blueberry-green tea-polyphenol soy protein complex (PSPC).
study_duration: 17 days (with a 3-day running period inserted at day 14).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of sinecatechins (green tea polyphenols) for treating viral and proliferative skin diseases, including genital warts and skin cancer.
results_summary: The study found that sinecatechins exhibit antiproliferative, pro-apoptotic, and antiviral activities, suggesting efficacy against genital warts and potential for treating other skin disorders. It also highlighted possible applications in photocarcinogenesis prevention and nonmelanoma skin cancer prevention.
population_specificity: Patients with external genital and perianal warts, and potentially other skin disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of short-term green tea extract (GTE) supplementation on resting energy expenditure, whole-body substrate utilization during exercise, and time trial performance in active men.
results_summary: GTE had minimal effects on whole-body substrate metabolism but significantly increased plasma glycerol and lowered heart rate during steady-state exercise, suggesting potential increases in lipolysis and cardiovascular effects. Time trial performance and other metabolic markers (e.g., glucose, insulin, free-fatty acids) were not different between GTE and placebo.
population_specificity: Fifteen active men (24 ± 3 years; VO2peak = 48 ± 7 ml/kg/min; BMI = 26 ± 3 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether polyphenol supplementation from green tea and blueberry extracts could mitigate inflammation and oxidative stress induced by intense training in long-distance runners.
results_summary: The study found that the polyphenol supplement enhanced gut-derived phenolic metabolites and ketogenesis during recovery but did not significantly affect established biomarkers for inflammation and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: 38 long-distance runners aged 19-45 years who regularly competed in road races.
effective_dosage: 40 g/d of polyphenol soy protein complex (PSPC) containing 2,136 mg/d gallic acid equivalents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms behind green tea's genoprotective effects, focusing on its impact on DNA repair enzymes and redox-sensitive adaptations.
results_summary: Green tea intake significantly reduced lymphocytic DNA damage (~30%) and increased activity of the DNA repair enzyme hOGG1 and heme oxygenase-1, indicating genoprotective effects from both single-dose and regular consumption.
population_specificity: 16 human subjects (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Single dose (200 mL of 1.5% w/v) and 7-day supplementation (2 × 200 mL of 1% w/v per day).
study_duration: Single-dose effects measured at 60 and 120 min; 7-day supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential protective role of green tea polyphenols (GTP), particularly in prostate neoplasia, and assess their mechanistic effects and clinical relevance.
results_summary: Preclinical studies suggest GTPs, especially EGCG, have proapoptotic and inhibitory effects on cancer pathways, but clinical trials show limited bioavailability and inconclusive efficacy in prostate neoplasia.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on prostate neoplasia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the cutaneous uptake of oral green tea catechins (GTC), their ability to protect human skin against UVR-induced erythema, and their impact on inflammatory mediators like PGE2 and 12-HETE.
results_summary: GTC intake led to the incorporation of catechin metabolites into human skin, reduced UVR-induced erythema, and decreased levels of the inflammatory mediator 12-HETE, though PGE2 levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy human subjects (phototype I/II), predominantly female (12/14 completers), median age 42.5 years (range 29-59).
effective_dosage: 540 mg GTC with 50 mg vitamin C daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the absorption, metabolism, and excretion of L-theanine from green tea and supplements in healthy participants.
results_summary: L-theanine was rapidly absorbed and metabolized into ethylamine and glutamic acid, with comparable kinetics and urinary excretion whether consumed via capsules or green tea. The study found dose-dependent increases in plasma L-theanine concentrations, suggesting functional effects may arise from L-theanine or its metabolites.
population_specificity: Healthy participants (n=12 for primary analysis, n=3 for additional dosage testing).
effective_dosage: 50 mg, 100 mg, and 200 mg L-theanine via capsules; 100 mg L-theanine via green tea.
study_duration: Blood and urine samples were collected up to 24 hours post-consumption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether green tea extract supplementation improves insulin resistance and cardiovascular risk factors in obese, hypertensive patients.
results_summary: The study found that green tea extract significantly reduced blood pressure, insulin resistance, inflammation, oxidative stress, and improved lipid profiles compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Obese, hypertensive patients (n=56)
effective_dosage: 379 mg of green tea extract daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether green tea catechins (GTC) supplementation could reduce cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk markers in active older adults participating in a walking program.
results_summary: GTC supplementation significantly reduced waist circumference, hip circumference, total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and LDL/HDL ratio in the intervention group, but no significant between-group differences were found. The study concluded that GTC did not significantly affect cardiovascular risk markers compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 52 older adults (mean age 69.1 ± 5.9 years, 20 male/32 female) participating in a pedometer-based walking program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the FDA's safety assessment and regulatory framework for botanical products, using green tea extracts as a case study.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about green tea's effects but discusses the FDA's approach to evaluating the safety of botanical products like green tea under regulatory frameworks.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether green tea extract supplementation combined with strength training enhances antioxidant defense and reduces oxidative stress and muscular damage in untrained men.
results_summary: Green tea extract supplementation increased plasma total polyphenols and antioxidant status at rest, reduced lipid hydroxyperoxides after exercise, and attenuated exercise-induced creatine kinase elevation compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Previously untrained male students.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of severe hepatotoxicity linked to a dietary supplement containing green tea, usnic acid, and guggul tree extracts, highlighting potential safety concerns.
results_summary: The study found that a dietary supplement containing green tea, usnic acid, and guggul tree extracts caused fulminant hepatic failure in a young healthy woman, requiring liver transplantation. It adds to existing reports of hepatotoxicity associated with such supplements.
population_specificity: A young healthy woman.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiangiogenesis mechanism of epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG) from green tea in an endometriosis model in vivo.
results_summary: EGCG inhibited microvessel formation in endometriotic implants by suppressing VEGFC/VEGFR2 signaling pathways, reducing endothelial proliferation, inflammatory response, and mobility. It also down-regulated VEGFC expression and reduced VEGFR2 and ERK activation in endothelial cells.
population_specificity: Immunocompromised mice with transplanted human endometrium from women with endometriosis (n = 10).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of green tea and its bioactive compounds on bone health, particularly in preventing bone loss and reducing osteoporotic fracture risk.
results_summary: The study found that green tea and its bioactive compounds may help mitigate bone loss in various models, including aging, sex hormone deficiency, and chronic inflammation, and showed potential benefits in postmenopausal women with low bone mass.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals, postmenopausal women, and models of bone loss (aging, sex hormone deficiency, chronic inflammation, obesity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of green tea beverage and extract on metabolic syndrome features and inflammation biomarkers in obese subjects.
results_summary: Green tea did not significantly alter metabolic syndrome features or most inflammation biomarkers but significantly reduced plasma serum amyloid alpha, a cardiovascular disease risk factor.
population_specificity: Obese subjects with metabolic syndrome (mean age 42.5 years, BMI 36.1 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 4 cups/day of green tea beverage or 2 capsules of green tea extract plus 4 cups water/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether three-week green tea extract (GTE) supplementation affects time trial performance and metabolism during cycling in endurance athletes.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of GTE on performance, energy metabolism, or most measured parameters, except for a reduction in C-reactive protein (CRP). GTE did not influence time trial performance or energy metabolism in endurance-trained men.
population_specificity: Nine endurance-trained men.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photoprotective effects of green tea polyphenols against UV-induced skin inflammation, oxidative stress, and DNA damage.
results_summary: The study found that green tea polyphenols demonstrated substantial photoprotective effects, reducing UV-induced skin inflammation, oxidative stress, and DNA damage, potentially lowering the risk of skin cancers.
population_specificity: Animal models (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a polyphenol-rich antioxidant supplement containing green tea extract could reduce oxidative stress and lipid peroxidation in Type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement significantly decreased LDL and plasma MDA while increasing HDL, total GSH, and antioxidant capacity compared to the placebo group. These effects suggest the supplement may help mitigate oxidative stress and lipid peroxidation in Type 2 diabetes.
population_specificity: 114 male and female non-smokers with Type 2 diabetes and no complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how green tea polyphenols (GTPs) influence diabetic wound healing by modulating apoptotic genes and circulating microRNAs.
results_summary: Green tea extract (GTE) improved wound healing in diabetic rats, enhancing wound contraction, epithelialization, and scar formation while altering levels of specific microRNAs (miR-21, miR-23a, miR-146a, miR-29b) and apoptotic genes (Bax, Caspase-3, Bcl-2).
population_specificity: Rats with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) induced by streptozotocin (STZ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal activity of KTZ-coated zinc oxide nanoparticles prepared using green tea extract and develop a novel antidandruff shampoo.
results_summary: The KTZ-coated ZnO nanoparticles showed enhanced antifungal activity against Malassezia furfur compared to standard KTZ (1%), with high drug entrapment efficiency (91.84%). The developed shampoo demonstrated ideal results, suggesting it could be an effective alternative to marketed anti-dandruff shampoos.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on in vitro antifungal activity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of green tea extract (GTE) on antioxidant status, oocyte developmental competence in buffaloes, and its protective effects on hepatic cells exposed to methanol insult.
results_summary: GTE supplementation improved antioxidant status, increased follicle count and oocyte quality, and enhanced blastocyst development in buffaloes. In vitro, GTE protected hepatic cells from methanol-induced damage by improving viability and SOD activity.
population_specificity: Italian Mediterranean buffaloes (in vivo) and cultured hepatic cells (in vitro).
effective_dosage: 0.5 μM and 1 μM (in vitro); dosage for buffaloes not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of green tea extract on A549 non-small lung cancer cells, focusing on cytotoxicity, apoptosis, and autophagy mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that green tea extract did not exhibit toxic effects on A549 cells, even at high doses (150 µM), and induced minimal apoptosis. However, it triggered autophagy, which appeared to act as a protective mechanism against cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: A549 non-small lung cancer cells (in vitro).
effective_dosage: Up to 150 µM of green tea extract.

study_goal: To determine the effect of EGCG (a component of Green Tea Extract) on tooth movement and root resorption during orthodontic treatment in rats.
results_summary: EGCG reduced orthodontic tooth movement (OTM) and root resorption, decreased osteoclastogenesis, and promoted osteogenesis, with stronger effects at 100 mg/kg than 50 mg/kg.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg and 100 mg/kg, administered by gavage

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether green tea extract extends lifespan and promotes health in genetically diverse Caenorhabditis species and strains.
results_summary: Green tea extract extended lifespan in a species-specific manner but showed assay-specific effects, including decreased survival in some genetic backgrounds and reduced oxidative stress resistance in certain strains. Its impact on older adult mobility was also dependent on genetic background.
population_specificity: Genetically diverse Caenorhabditis species and strains (C. elegans and related species).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the combined treatment of heat-treated green tea extract (HTGT) and enzymatically modified isoquercitrin (EMIQ) has synergistic anti-obesity effects in mice fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: The co-treatment of HTGT and EMIQ demonstrated a synergistic anti-obesity effect, reducing body weight gain, adipocyte hypertrophy, total body fat mass, and abdominal fat volume more effectively than orlistat. It also increased energy expenditure, glucose intolerance, and upregulated genes linked to mitochondrial oxidative metabolism and lipolysis.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a mudflat hiking tour on students' environmental attitudes and knowledge.
results_summary: The study found that the mudflat hiking tour had positive short-term and long-term effects on both environmental attitudes and knowledge, with correlation analyses supporting a positive relationship between these constructs.
population_specificity: 427 secondary school students (mean age: 11.74 years)
study_duration: Not specified (pre-post-test design with retention test)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of mountain hiking on physiological, psychological, and immunological parameters in sedentary couples, comparing it to forest therapy.
results_summary: The study found that a seven-day moderate hiking program improved health-related quality of life and relationship quality, along with secondary outcomes like cardio-respiratory fitness and body composition. A novel comic-based tool was also validated for assessing health-related quality of life.
population_specificity: Sedentary couples

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a single mowing event could reduce the abundance of host-seeking ticks on recreational trails to lower the risk of human-tick encounters.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in adult tick abundance between mown and control trail sections. Mowing slightly increased nymphal tick abundance, suggesting it was ineffective for reducing tick-related risks on trails.
population_specificity: Recreational trails in three parks in northern Minnesota.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was a single mowing event).
study_duration: 7 weeks (pre-intervention sampling followed by six weeks of post-intervention sampling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively evaluate the effects of adapted hiking on quality of life and self-efficacy in individuals with motor disabilities.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in wheelchair confidence (WheelCon-M scores) among participants after adapted hiking, suggesting enhanced confidence in wheelchair management. No other outcome measures showed significant changes.
population_specificity: 34 individuals with motor disabilities (28 manual wheelchair users, 6 electric wheelchair users), average age 41 years.
study_duration: Intervention duration not specified; follow-up assessments were conducted three weeks post-activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of forest therapy and mountain hiking on health-related quality of life, relationship quality, and other psychological and physiological parameters in sedentary or inactive couples.
results_summary: The study found that both men and women with sedentary lifestyles experienced mental health benefits (e.g., improved quality of life, mood) from nature-based interventions, with women showing notable physiological improvements (e.g., aerobic capacity, skeletal muscle mass) from mountain hiking. Small blood pressure improvements were observed in both genders.
population_specificity: Sedentary or inactive couples (healthy and highly functioning women and men).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dual-task orienteering and single-task hiking on gait performance and cognitive function in older adults.
results_summary: The hiking group (HG) showed modest improvements in task cost (24%) and cognitive functions (16.5% in executive functions/visuospatial skills, 14.7% in processing speed, and 6.5% in memory), though these were less pronounced than the orienteering group's results.
population_specificity: Independent older adults (n=90, divided into three groups: orienteering, hiking, and control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a biweekly group-based hiking program could improve health-related quality of life, cardiorespiratory fitness, and psychological outcomes in older adults, comparing previously inactive and active participants.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in physical health-related quality of life, cardiorespiratory fitness, and psychological outcomes (e.g., self-efficacy, competency) in previously inactive older adults. Active participants maintained similar exercise intensity but reported lower perceived exertion.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 55-75, divided into previously inactive (n=13) and active (n=14) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether a winter hiking intervention affected activity choices and aspects of well-being, including hiking frequency, stress, and sleep duration, during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The intervention increased hiking frequency and improved sleep when winter traction cleats were provided, but no significant effects on stress were observed. Engagement in the hiking challenge was higher in the second study when equipment barriers were addressed.
population_specificity: Convenience samples of adults (n=53 and n=51) in two separate randomized studies conducted in 2021 and 2022.
effective_dosage: Not specified (free access to a regional winter hiking challenge and provision of winter traction cleats in the second study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of nature hiking versus urban hiking as interventions for military Veterans with PTSD.
results_summary: Both nature and urban hiking were highly acceptable, with over 70% positive ratings. Nature hiking showed greater improvement in PTSD symptoms at 12 and 24 weeks compared to urban hiking.
population_specificity: Military Veterans with PTSD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of mountain hiking and psychological coaching on aerobic capacity, spirometry, and quality of life in sedentary adults.
results_summary: The study found that both hiking and coaching improved quality of life, with coaching showing a greater improvement in aerobic capacity for female participants. No significant effects were observed for spirometry.
population_specificity: Sedentary adults (n = 58, with 26 in the coaching group and 32 in the hiking group).
effective_dosage: 7-day guided hiking program with three personal coaching sessions for the coaching group; hiking group received no coaching.
study_duration: 7-day intervention with follow-up assessments at day 7 and day 80.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the acute effects of a three-hour outdoor mountain hiking intervention on affective responses compared to a sedentary control and indoor treadmill walking.
results_summary: Outdoor mountain hiking significantly increased positive affective responses (valence, activation, elation, calmness) and decreased negative responses (fatigue, anxiety) compared to both the sedentary control and indoor treadmill walking. The effects were more pronounced for outdoor hiking than indoor walking.
population_specificity: 42 healthy participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the acute effects of a three-hour green exercise intervention (mountain hiking) on stress-related physiological responses compared to indoor treadmill walking and a sedentary control condition.
results_summary: Three hours of hiking (both outdoors and indoors) led to a larger decrease in salivary cortisol compared to the sedentary condition, but no significant differences were found in heart rate variability or blood pressure between the three conditions. Environmental effects appeared minor for the measured physiological responses.
population_specificity: 42 healthy participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the development of foot lesions during hiking and the influence of preexisting physical characteristics such as skin disorders, nail disorders, and toe deformities.
results_summary: The study found that preexisting physical factors like gender, systemic disease, keratosis, dermatosis, onychopathies, and toe deformities significantly predispose hikers to foot and muscle lesions. It recommends checking these factors before hiking and ensuring proper podiatry treatment and warmup to reduce foot disorders.
population_specificity: 109 hikers undertaking a 29.6-km hike.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 3-month guided hiking program improves functional abilities and quality of life in patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The intervention group showed faster walking times on the stair climb test and significant improvements in some QoL subscales compared to the control group, with no acute detrimental effects observed.
population_specificity: Elderly patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health benefits of hiking as a cost-effective intervention to promote physical activity and overall wellness.
results_summary: Hiking was found to provide immediate benefits like reduced blood pressure and stress, as well as long-term benefits such as weight loss and improved mental health. The study also highlighted partnerships between health care providers and natural resource agencies to promote hiking.
population_specificity: General population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an adaptive management approach in reducing off-trail hiking behavior in a heavily visited urban-proximate park area.
results_summary: The study found that a comprehensive treatment combining educational and site management actions reduced intentional off-trail hiking from 70.3% to 43.0% based on visitor reports, and direct observations showed a reduction from 25.9% to 2.0%. Both educational messaging and site management contributed to the decline in off-trail travel.
population_specificity: Visitors to a popular trail in the Chesapeake and Ohio National Historical Park near Washington DC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how educational messages and visual displays of trail degradation influence hikers' behavioral intentions regarding responsible hiking.
results_summary: The study found that neither educational messages nor image display methods consistently affected hikers' intentions, but trail degradation type (muddiness) and severity significantly influenced off-trail hiking intent. Gender and hiking frequency also impacted behavioral intentions, with women more likely to turn around and less likely to hike off-trail than men.
population_specificity: Participants in a lab-based experiment (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of hiking on maximal exercise capacity, aerobic capability, and markers of suicidality in high-risk suicidal patients.
results_summary: Hiking significantly improved maximal exercise capacity and aerobic capability without worsening markers of suicidality. Cytokines associated with suicidality remained unchanged.
population_specificity: High-risk suicidal patients (n = 20).
effective_dosage: 2-3 hikes per week, each lasting 2-2.5 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the risks associated with hiking, particularly those linked to food found in forests, such as echinococcosis and mushroom poisoning.
results_summary: The study highlights that echinococcosis, a parasite affecting foxes, can infect humans through contaminated berries, and prevention is key to avoiding mushroom poisoning. Treatment for poisoning is symptomatic, using activated charcoal.
population_specificity: General population in Switzerland, particularly hikers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cardiovascular effects of hiking at moderate altitude compared to low altitude in patients with metabolic syndrome, assessing potential altitude-specific benefits.
results_summary: Both altitude groups showed significant weight loss and improved cardiovascular parameters (reduced blood pressure and heart rate profiles), with no differences between groups, suggesting benefits stem from regular physical activity rather than altitude.
population_specificity: 71 male patients with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: 12 hiking tours (4 per week, average duration 2.5 hours, intensity 55%–65% of heart rate maximum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether endurance training through mountain hiking could improve hopelessness, depression, and suicide ideation in high-risk suicide patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in hopelessness, depression, and physical endurance during the hiking phase, with a notable decrease in suicide ideation within the hiking phase but no significant effect when comparing phases.
population_specificity: High-risk suicide patients with a history of at least one suicide attempt and clinical diagnosis of hopelessness.
study_duration: 9 weeks per phase (total 18 weeks with crossover)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the risks associated with hiking, particularly focusing on insect stings and snake bites in Switzerland.
results_summary: The study identified insect stings (wasps and bees) and snake bites as significant risks for hikers, with systemic effects ranging from renal failure to hypovolemic shock. Pre-hospitalization measures were emphasized as crucial for treatment.
population_specificity: General population in Switzerland, with specific mention of allergic individuals (around 5% of the population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a treatment plan for blisters caused by friction in pilgrims hiking the Road to Santiago, focusing on comfort, security, and prevention of complications.
results_summary: The study treated 16 lesions with a procedure involving precocious debridement, a nitrofurazone-based wet cure, and bandaging, resulting in favorable evolution within six days and no significant differences in improvement.
population_specificity: Pilgrims hiking the Road to Santiago (traveling companions of the authors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of a 3-week hiking vacation at moderate and low altitudes on key markers of the metabolic syndrome in men.
results_summary: The study found that a 3-week hiking vacation significantly improved body weight, body fat, waist circumference, fasting glucose, cholesterol levels, and blood pressure in both altitude groups, with no clinically relevant differences between them. Fasting insulin and HOMA-index improved in the low-altitude group, while relative cycle ergometry performance increased in both groups post-vacation.
population_specificity: 71 male volunteers aged 36-66 years with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: 12 moderate-intensity guided hiking tours (4 times/week, 55-65% HRmax) totaling 29 hours of exercise plus moderate recreational activities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and acclimatization process of hiking at elevations above 1500 m, focusing on preventing altitude-related illnesses.
results_summary: The study found that proper acclimatization, controlled ascent speed, and sleeping elevation are critical to avoiding altitude sickness. Severe cases require immediate descent and therapy, while mild symptoms are generally harmless.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals hiking at elevations above 1500 m.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if histidine-derived carbon dots (His-CDs) could effectively detect staurosporine-induced apoptosis in Jurkat cells.
results_summary: His-CDs demonstrated biocompatibility, effective cellular uptake, and concentration-dependent fluorescence in detecting apoptosis, which was confirmed to be caspase-3 dependent.
population_specificity: T lymphoma (Jurkat) cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an antiperspirant (20% aluminum chloride hexahydrate) could reduce foot blisters during hiking.
results_summary: The antiperspirant reduced blister incidence (21% vs. 48% in placebo) when used for at least 3 nights, but caused significant skin irritation (57% vs. 6% in placebo).
population_specificity: US Military Academy cadets
effective_dosage: 20% aluminum chloride hexahydrate in anhydrous ethyl alcohol, applied for 5 consecutive nights

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of induced painful sensation (via Beta Alanine ingestion) on Love and Care of Nature, heart rate, perceived exertion, and pain during outdoor hiking.
results_summary: The study found no difference in heart rate between Beta Alanine and placebo groups during the hike, but other outcomes (LCN, RPE, MPQ) were not reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 20 volunteers participating in consecutive-day hikes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of chronic sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃) supplementation on physiological and performance-related parameters during a high-altitude hiking tour.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in performance-related parameters between the bicarbonate and control groups, but urinary pH was significantly higher in the bicarbonate group, suggesting some metabolic impact.
population_specificity: Ten recreationally active subjects participating in a 7-day hiking tour in the Swiss Alps up to 4554 m above sea level.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term environmental impacts of mountain biking and hiking on understory vegetation and soil in a deciduous forest.
results_summary: Hiking and mountain biking had similar effects on vegetation and soil, causing significant short-term reductions in plant stem density and species richness, as well as increased soil exposure. These impacts were no longer detectable one year later, indicating rapid recovery when activities were discontinued.
population_specificity: Deciduous forest habitat in Boyne Valley Provincial Park, Ontario, Canada.
study_duration: Measurements taken before treatment, two weeks after, and one year after.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether histidine-rich glycoprotein (HRG) could suppress TNF-α-induced angiogenesis in human endothelial cells and explore the role of NRF2 in this process.
results_summary: HRG effectively suppressed TNF-α-induced tube formation and downregulated integrins αV and β8 expression. It promoted NRF2 nuclear translocation, which played a key role in HRG's antiangiogenic effects.
population_specificity: Human endothelial cells (EA.hy926)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of histidine (HIS) in the therapeutic effects of Panax notoginseng saponins (PNS) on ischemic stroke (IS) via the gut-brain axis, focusing on its neuroprotective mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that histidine levels were significantly reduced in IS patients and I/R rats, and L. reuteri colonization increased HIS in serum, gut microbiota, and brain, demonstrating neuroprotective effects. Exogenous HIS also showed indirect neuroprotective activity through histamine metabolism.
population_specificity: Clinical obsolete IS patients and ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) model rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of histidine metabolism in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) progression, immune regulation, and its impact on tumor microenvironment.
results_summary: The study found that dysregulated histidine metabolism in HCC promotes tumor growth and immune evasion by impairing macrophage and T-cell function, with BUD23 identified as a key gene negatively correlated with survival and immune infiltration. Silencing BUD23 reversed immunosuppressive effects, suggesting potential therapeutic targets.
population_specificity: Patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Umbelliferone (UMB) could mitigate cyclophosphamide-induced immunosuppression by regulating histidine and purine metabolism.
results_summary: UMB improved immune function in immunosuppressed mice by enhancing histidine metabolism, increasing levels of histamine and related metabolites, and reducing oxidative stress and apoptosis.
population_specificity: CTX-immunosuppressed mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the tautomeric conformations of histidine-containing dipeptides and tripeptides in Tau protein and their identification via IR spectroscopy and NMR shielding.
results_summary: The study found that IR spectra of the N-H group and NMR shielding of imidazole ring carbon atoms can identify histidine-containing peptide tautomers. Analysis of hydrogen bonding, atomic charge distribution, and HOMO-LUMO transitions supported these findings.
population_specificity: Not applicable (computational study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antitumor activity and mechanisms of the histidine-rich peptide rAj-HRP30 in pancreatic cancer cells.
results_summary: rAj-HRP30 significantly inhibited adhesion, migration, and invasion of pancreatic cancer cells (Panc01 and Panc02), disrupted cellular morphology, and induced apoptosis via FGFR1-related signaling pathways. It also downregulated MMP2 and MMP9 expression, further inhibiting cancer cell migration and invasion.
population_specificity: Human (Panc01) and mouse (Panc02) pancreatic cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how B. animalis BD400 affects histidine metabolism in gut microbiota and its role in alleviating rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: B. animalis BD400 down-regulated 1-methyl-L-histidine and urocanate in histidine metabolism, which contributed to reduced inflammation and slowed RA progression in rats. The treatment also improved intestinal barrier function and altered gut microbiota composition.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rat model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of histidine triad nucleotide-binding protein 2 (HINT2) in mitigating doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity (DIC) by restoring NAD+/NADH ratio, lysosomal function, and autophagy.
results_summary: HINT2 upregulation protected against DIC by improving mitochondrial function and lysosomal activity, while its deficiency worsened cardiac dysfunction. Nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN) supplementation and HINT2 overexpression alleviated DIC in vivo and in vitro.
population_specificity: DOX-treated mice and in vitro models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the rare occurrence of clinically significant iron overload in individuals with H63D heterozygous hereditary hemochromatosis and its association with erythrocytosis.
results_summary: The study found that an asymptomatic H63D heterozygous individual developed iron overload and erythrocytosis, responding well to venesection treatment. It highlights the need to consider HFE gene mutations in idiopathic erythrocytosis cases.
population_specificity: An asymptomatic Sinhalese man with H63D heterozygous hereditary hemochromatosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Histidine 105 in the activation of soluble guanylyl cyclase (sGC) by different generations of sGC activators and propose a new classification for these activators.
results_summary: The study found that Histidine 105 is crucial for heme binding and activation of sGC by NO, with second-generation activators (runcaciguat and BAY 543) requiring this residue for activity, unlike first-generation activators (cinaciguat and BAY 60-2770). The findings suggest a need to re-evaluate previous research using sGC histidine mutants.
population_specificity: β1 H105F knock-in mice and in vitro sGC mutants (α1/β1H105F and α1/β1H105A).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the bioavailability of rumen-protected histidine (RPHis) compared to free histidine and other amino acids using three in vivo methods.
results_summary: The study found that RPHis had a bioavailability of 45% (AUC method) and 87% (FFAA method), indicating moderate to high absorption efficiency. The results were consistent with prior estimates, though variability between methods highlights challenges in accurate measurement.
population_specificity: 8 rumen-cannulated cows in a replicated Latin square design.
effective_dosage: Not specified (pulse-dose and continuous infusion methods used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the recombinant histidine-rich peptide rAj-HRP derived from Apostichopus japonicus could inhibit colon cancer growth in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: rAj-HRP inhibited HCT116 colon cancer cell proliferation, migration, and adhesion in vitro, disrupted the cytoskeleton, and induced apoptosis. In vivo, it significantly reduced tumor volume and weight in BALB/c mice without affecting body weight, likely through EGFR and apoptosis pathways.
population_specificity: Human colon cancer HCT116 cells and BALB/c mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence and impact of pfhrp2 gene deletions in P. falciparum infections on malaria diagnostic accuracy and intervention effectiveness in Odisha, India.
results_summary: The study found that 61.6% of subpatent P. falciparum infections had pfhrp2 gene deletions, primarily in exon 2, and identified novel amino acid repeat motifs in intact pfhrp2 loci. Mass screening and treatment combined with other interventions reduced infection risk for both pfhrp2-deleted and intact parasites.
population_specificity: Febrile individuals and malaria-endemic villages in Odisha, India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the non-inferiority of NPC-25 (zinc histidine hydrate) to NOBELZIN™ (zinc acetate dihydrate) in efficacy and safety for treating hypozincemia.
results_summary: NPC-25 demonstrated non-inferiority to NOBELZIN™ in maintaining target serum zinc levels, with a tendency for earlier achievement and lower daily doses. Safety assessments showed fewer digestive symptoms (nausea, vomiting) with NPC-25 compared to NOBELZIN™.
population_specificity: Patients with hypozincemia (serum zinc <70 μg/dL).
effective_dosage: Initial daily doses of 50 mg or 100 mg, adjusted to maintain target serum zinc levels.
study_duration: Up to 24 weeks (extendable to 52 weeks for NPC-25 group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which Histidine phosphatase (LHPP) induces ferroptosis and enhances tumor immunogenicity in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) treatment.
